items.message:
High river levels have begun to recede throughout today and are exepcted to reced further druing Wednesday.
The risk of flooding remains for the remainder of Tuesday 25/02/25 and into Wednesday 26/02/25.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.
Weather conditions are expected to continue to improve tomorrow and no additional flooding is expected, despite further rainfall being forecast for Wednesday.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
This message will be updated by 4.00 PM on 26/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. River levels are forecast to rise following further rainfall this morning, 26/02/25 and remain high until Thursday, 27/02/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated this evening, 26/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but stable on the River Windrush following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water and Newbridge. The weather forecast for today is for further heavy rain which should clear overnight. Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and to remain responsive to further rainfall. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising quickly on the River Thames following recent  rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 26/02/2025. The weather forecast for the rest of today is showers. We expect river levels to continue to rise for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid contact with flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Rivers across the South East Somerset Catchment remain high as a result of the rainfall that fell throughout Sunday.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Today, Wednesday 26/02/25 is forecast for some periods of rain which may result in river levels rising again. 
We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels and will continue to assess the situation.
Please take care and avoid walking, cycling, or driving through floodwaters. Flooding of roads and low-lying areas is possible, but property flooding is not expected at this stage. 
This message will be updated by 11AM on 26/02/2025, or sooner if conditions change.

items.message: River levels in the Lower Avon remain high due to high groundwater and the recent rainfall.  A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. Rainfall is forecast for the 26th. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 10:00 AM on 26/02/2025. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.

We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and continue to rise at the Stinsford river gauge on the Lower Frome.  

Flooding is forecast to affect low lying areas to start with near to the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool, East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas. 
 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Flood Alert if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now and watch your local weather forecast. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 9:30 AM on 26/02/2025.
Areas most at risk include roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.
Further flooding is possible throughout the afternoon as river levels are rising rapidly due to periods of heavy rainfall.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:58 AM on 26/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am, Thursday the 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, but standing water and debris may still remain.

Further rainfall is forecast this morning but no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station has decreased to 8.33m. The drain level at the station however has risen and is currently 7.51m 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi pumping station as soon as possible when river levels fall further. This looks likely to happen soon as the outlook for the next few days remains relatively dry. Weather conditions are forecast to improve following a small band of rain on Wednesday morning. 
Staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on road closures.
This message will be updated by 11am on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes

Rising river levels this afternoon may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Shalford and Southmarsh and the confluence with the River Stour. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon. We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
Rising river levels are causing flooding throughout the afternoon.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary.

Further flooding is expected this afternoon and into the evening as river levels are rising due to heavy rainfall last night.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Activate any property flood protection products you may have. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Refer to local authority website for road closures. Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area.
This Flood Alert is no longer in force.
The risk of flooding has reduced, however we will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this alert if necessary.

The Cuckmere River is a little higher than normal in Alfriston, but slowly falling, following Monday morning's rain. In Hellingly, the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers have already fallen nearer to a normal level. 5 to 10mm of rain is forecast between 10:00 and 15:00 Wednesday. Rivers will rise, but are expected to peak lower than Monday. From 13:00 26/02/2025 minor flooding could again affect gardens on Mill Lane Hellingly. From 16:00 26/02/2025 minor flooding could affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 22:00 26/02/2025 minor flooding could affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, and fields near Alfriston. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 23:00 26/02/2025 in Hellingly, and 11:00 27/02/2025 in Alfriston. All river levels should return nearer to normal by Friday afternoon. Please plan to avoid driving on routes that flood, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

The Western Rother is high in Fittleworth, and higher than normal near Selham, but currently falling in all communities. Flood water will be near to properties at Fittleworth Mill. At Lodsbridge, near Selham, flooding will continue to affect roads, and fields. Between Liss and Midhurst river levels have already fallen significantly and only minimal residual flood impacts are expected. 10mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 Wednesday. The Western Rother will rise a little in all communities, but will peak lower than Monday. Only minor flood impacts, affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens are expected. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 18:00 26/02/2025 in Liss, and 20:00 27/02/2025 in Fittleworth. River levels should return nearer to normal by Thursday near Liss, but not until the weekend near Fittleworth. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday.
Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the area. Rivers have risen overnight and we expect the rivers to remain high throughout today.
There will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 26/02/2025. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Observed peaks:- Upper Pound, Tewkesbury 2.99m overnight Monday 24/02/2025 and Mythe 2.88 overnight Tuesday 25/02/2025. Further scattered showers are forecast during the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high, but slowly fall over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on Wednesday 26/02/25, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next few days. Our incident response staff are continuing to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded

The weather forecast for today is for further heavy rain  which should clear overnight. Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry. floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message: The River Adur has fallen significantly, following Monday morning's rain. Only minimal residual flood impacts affecting fields are expected to remain. 5mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 Wednesday. The River Adur will rise a small amount but will peak significantly lower than Monday. From 15:00 26/02/2025 minimal flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens could be possible. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 06:00 27/02/2025, and should return nearer to normal by Friday. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flooding, please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

The River Ouse has fallen near to normal, following Monday morning's rain. Only minimal residual flood impacts affecting fields are expected to remain. 5 to 10mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 Wednesday. The River Ouse will rise a small amount, but will peak lower than Monday. Minimal flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens could be possible in communities near Ardingly from 15:00 26/02/2025, and from 19:00 26/02/2025 near Barcombe. Minor flooding could again affect gardens on Sloop Lane, roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge, and possibly fields near the Anchor Inn, near Barcombe Mills. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 22:00 26/02/2025 near Ardingly, and 08:00 27/02/2025 near Barcombe. The river should return nearer to a normal level by Friday. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

River levels are high and rising at the Hammoon river gauge on the River Stour as a result of overnight heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low-lying land, roads and farmland is possible. There is a possibility of flooding for tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, consider installing property flood resilience equipment, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11.00 AM 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the River Loddon as a result of heavy rainfall, especially in the Sindlesham Mill area. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with some localised heavier rainfall in some areas. We are monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are now falling at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 4.09m at 5.30am Monday morning, 24/02/2025; Cae Howel peaked at 4.14m at 10.45am on Tuesday 25/02/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ebble, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alvediston and Nunton. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon.

We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.
 
This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: Groundwater levels are being kept high from previous heavy rainfall this week. They are very slowly starting to drop. We are expecting some further rainfall coming through on Wednesday. This may keep the groundwater levels high. Flooding of fields and roads is possible. Areas most at risk include: the Iwerne and the Pimperne Brook areas. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.

River levels in the River Bourne remain high due to the high groundwater and the recent rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected at the moment. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. Rainfall is forecast for the 26th. We are monitoring the rainfall and the river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor your local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/2/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brit at Newtown, and Southgate Old Mill, Beaminster
items.message:
Rising river levels are causing flooding throughout the morning.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Brit. Areas most at risk include properties in Southgate and Newtown in Beaminster.

Further flooding is expected throughout the morning as river levels are rising rapidly due to heavy rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.

Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Activate any property flood protection products you may have. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this morning. Flooding is expected from 10:30 AM on 26/02/2025. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Dorchester Road and Frome Lane area of Maiden Newton. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.

We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 26/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wylye, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the morning. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to be high at Briantspuddle river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to recent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the Piddle and tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  
Further rainfall is expected over the next few days.  The groundwater levels are high and helping sustain the current high river levels.  River levels can rise quickly in response to rainfall. 

Owners should continue to use any property flood resilience equipment installed.  Please avoid using low lying paths and bridges over local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on 25/02/25 by 12 noon, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high on the River Kennet following recent heavy rainfall but levels are starting to fall slowly. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue for the next few days, especially in areas close to the river around  Calcot and Theale. The weather forecast for today is for further heavy rain which should clear overnight. Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly through today. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high at the River Loddon at the Thames confluence at Twyford, as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, with low lying land adjacent to the river is expected, especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads affecting access to properties. 

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with some localised heavier rainfall in some areas. We are monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but still within banks along most of the Upper Kennet. However, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in areas close to the River Dun near Hungerford where river levels are high but stable. The weather forecast for today is for further heavy rain which should clear overnight. Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry.  We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Winterbourne Stream in Bagnor and the River Lambourn in Newbury. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue and we expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the next few days. The weather forecast for today is for further heavy rain which should clear overnight. Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from East Stoke to Wareham
Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message: River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to the recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk include areas in Britford, Charlton All Saints, Downton and Fordingbridge in close proximity to the River Avon. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 4pm on the 26/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from Dorchester to East Stoke
River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, especially in the Shiplake and Wargrave areas. 

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with the potential for heavier rainfall in localised areas. We expect river levels to continue to rise as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. 

Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising in Blewbury following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low -lying land and roads is possible today 26/02/2025, especially in the area around Blewbury. The weather forecast for today is for a heavy spell of rain this morning followed by showers. We expect river levels to rise in relation to the rainfall.  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water.  This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible,  especially in the Henley, Remenham, and Medmenham areas. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with the potential for heavier rainfall in localised areas. We expect river levels to continue to rise as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising on the River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible for the next few days. 

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with the potential for heavier rainfall in localised areas. We expect river levels to continue to remain high as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. 

Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

The River Lox has returned near to a normal level, following Monday's rain. 10mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 Wednesday. The River Lox will rise a little in all communities, but will peak lower than Monday. From 16:00 26/02/2025 minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens could be possible along the length of the River Lox. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 02:00 27/02/2025 near Loxwood, and should return nearer to normal by Thursday evening, earlier upstream. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

The River Adur has fallen significantly, following Monday morning's rain. Only minimal residual flood impacts affecting fields are expected to remain. 5mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 on Wednesday. The River Adur will rise a small amount in all communities, but will peak significantly lower than Monday. From 13:00 26/02/2025 minimal flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens could be possible. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 21:00 26/02/2025 near Coolham, and should return nearer to normal by Thursday afternoon. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may be affected by flooding. Please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

River levels are high and rising at the Salisbury Harnham Bridge gauge on the Middle Hampshire Avon.  Areas most at risk include St Nicholas Road, the Close in Salisbury.  We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local.  Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and consider putting your flood plan into action.  Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Residents are strongly urged to take action now.  Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.  This message will be updated by 4pm on the 26/02/25, or as the situation changes

items.description: Windle Brook and Hale, Mill and Addlestone Bournes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on The Addlestone Bourne, as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. 

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with some localised heavier rainfall in some areas. We are monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message: The River Arun is high near Pallingham Lock, but now slowly falling, following Monday's rain. Flood water will continue to affect gardens and fields near Pallingham Lock. Nearer Horsham, river levels have already fallen significantly and only minimal residual flood impacts are expected. 10mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 13:00 Wednesday. The river will rise a little in all communities, but will peak lower than Monday. Only minor flood impacts, affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens are expected. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will begin to fall by 22:00 26/02/2025 in Horsham, and 14:00 27/02/2025 at Pallingham Lock. River levels should return nearer to normal by Thursday near Horsham, but not until the weekend near Pallingham Lock. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to reduce flood risk in Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area.
This Flood Alert is no longer in force.
The risk of flooding has reduced, however we will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this alert if necessary.

The River Arun is high, but now slowly falling at Pulborough. Water will continue to be in fields and could affect the A29, and gardens on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday morning, but the river level at Pulborough is expected to continue falling. Tide levels are now rising. Peak water levels in Amberley and Arundel on Wednesday (11:00 and 23:00) are expected to be 30cm higher than Tuesday. Water levels will be higher again on Thursday, and close to the top of the banks in Amberley, but property flooding is not currently expected. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will remain higher than normal through to next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 27/02/2025.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
The Colne Brook is beginning to fall slowly.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Areas most at risk include Colnbrook Village; Poyle; Albany Park; High Street; Mill Street; Fawsley Close and Myrtle Close.
Further showers are forecast for today.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 6pm on 26/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. This Flood Alert is no longer in force. The risk of flooding has reduced, however we will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are remaining high due to previous rainfall. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. We are expecting some further rainfall coming on Wednesday (26th). This may keep the levels high. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

The forecast is for some further light rainfall over the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels are falling but remain above the Flood Alert threshold. Flooding remains possible today, 26/02/2025. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook.  Further rainfall is forecast today, which may see levels rise again, however we are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 5pm this afternoon, Wednesday 26/02/25.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.   Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising slowly. In the last week, over a month’s rain (65mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. At Preston Candover, the level has risen by 17cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to rise over the next 2 weeks. It is possible that isolated properties in Old Alresford could experience internal ground floor flooding in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 26th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 26th February 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall. . Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising quickly on the Hughenden Stream in High Wycombe following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 26/02/2025, especially in the Hughenden area of High Wycombe. The weather forecast for today is for a heavy spell of rain this morning followed by showers. We expect river levels to continue to rise for the next few hours. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water.  This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and rising slowly. During the last week, nearly a month’s rain (56mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. During this time, the level at Hursley has risen by 16cm. Most of the village are now expected to be experiencing cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to rise over the next week. Internal ground floor flooding is possible in the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: In the villages surrounding Andover, groundwater levels are high and relatively stable. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (32mm) has been recorded at Andover. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw and Hatherden, and is possible in Penton Grafton. Groundwater is flooding the main road into Penton Grafton and is emerging into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton. Impacts to the sewerage systems in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). If the heavier rain in the forecast affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise and cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flood risk in Thruxton could occur in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and rising slowly. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (40mm) has been recorded at Overton. During this time, the level at Oakley has risen by 13cm. In Deane, cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising well into March in response to the rain already recorded this week. In early-March, it is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Wylye from Brixton Deverill to Warminster
items.message: River levels are high and rising on the Upper River Wylye from Brixton Deverill to Warminster due to the heavy rainfall this morning.  Areas affected are Longbridge Deverills, Henfords Marsh, Boreham, Water Lane and Norton Bavant.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements.  River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

The forecast is unsettled for the next 5 days with the potential for blustery showers later in the week. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. 
 
This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 26th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. During the last week, almost a month’s rain (45mm) has been recorded at Broughton. At Lopcombe, the level has fallen by 1.12m. At West Tytherley, the level has risen by 18cm. Minor flooding to land, gardens and the sewerage system is possible. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels at Lopcombe are expected to begin rising again in the next few days, in response to rain recorded in the last week. Ongoing flooding impacts will increase and cellar flooding in Nether Wallop may occur. At West Tytherley, the level is expected to continue rising slowly for another week. It is possible that flooding to cellars, land and roads could occur in the village in the next few days. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message: Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Gunner, Winterbourne Dauntsey, Winterbourne Earls and Laverstock . The groundwater level at the Clarendon borehole continue to rise. We are expecting some further rainfall on Wednesday (26th). We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.

River levels are rising rapidly in the River Brit due overnight heavy rainfall.  Areas most at risk are at Bridge Street and Crook Hill in Netherbury .  Flooding of property is possible.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brit at Riverside and George Street, West Bay
items.message:
Flooding is likely because the river and its streams are high and rapidly rising due to the rain this morning.
Act fast and act now to protect yourself, your family and help others. 
Land, infrastructure and properties are expected to be affected in locations near the River Brit with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected , particularly around Riverside and George Street, West Bay. We are not expecting very much further rain. We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with flood asset operators and partners.
Fast moving flood water will be dangerous and may contain hazards. Avoid contact with it and do not 
walk or drive through it. We will update this message by 10:00 AM on 27/02/2025, or as the situation changes.
